State and Private Forestry, Forest Service

title.narrative: African Swine Fever Response

description.narrative: In July 2021, APHIS confirmed the presence of African swine fever (ASF) in the Dominican Republic, near the border with Haiti. Epidemic outbreaks of ASF can result in significant economic impacts, depending on the duration of the outbreak, extent of trade embargoes, and reaction of producers and consumers to the disease and response measures. APHIS has been working with the Dominican Republic Ministry of Agriculture to develop an enhanced surveillance strategy to identify infected farms and support response actions, including testing, depopulation, and cleaning and disinfection. This project (conducted in cooperation with OIRSA) provides funding and support to 1) ensure that field staff have the resources, supplies, and training needed to carry out these activities and allow the response to scale up for more rapid control of the spread of ASF; 2) enhance veterinary laboratory capacity and biosecurity to conduct diagnostic testing associated with the response; and 3) enhance biocontainment through placing canine detector dogs and incinerators at airports to prevent the international spread of ASF.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: CSF control and eradication programs in Haiti and DR

description.narrative: CSF control and eradication programs in Haiti and DR, has been in place since 2003 with the technical and financial support of USDA-APHIS. The DR and Haiti CSF programs rely on the technical advice from USDA-APHIS-VS experts. Specific recommendations to improve CSF programs field operations in Haiti and DR, are provided by APHIS experts in the areas of vaccination (quality and quantity), CSF epidemiological surveillance, sample collection procedures and biosecurity . Given the level of underfunding of the CSF program in Haiti and the termination of APHIS funding for the DR program, the recommendations provided by APHIS-VS experts are important to identify priority actions and realistic goals for the program in the future. FAS food for progress funds will be available shortly to continue the support to the DR CSF eradication program beyond 2012. At this critical moment, the DR CVO and the Veterinary Services are designing a 2 year plan to complete CSF eradication in the DR.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Training Workshop on Animal Disease Recognition and Response

description.narrative: From April 19-23, 2016, Dominican Republic officials participated in a Train the Trainers Workshop on Animal and Zoonotic Disease Recognition and Response. The Dominican Republic Veterinary Services contacted the USDA-APHIS-IS office in Santo Domingo to request a subject matter expert to lecture on Anthrax.

title.narrative: Training on Good Emergency Management Practice (GEMP) for Animal Health

description.narrative: From July 3-14, 2016, a meeting was conducted between FAO with OIE, IICA, OIRSA and APHIS representatives to discuss and develop a roadmap in support of both countries continued improvement in their control and eradication of classical swine fever from the island. Along with colleagues at FAO and APHIS-IS, co-facilitated the GEMP Workshop.

title.narrative: Avian Influenza Risk Mapping and risk-based surveillance Train the Training workshop

description.narrative: From July 10-16, 2016, the Avian Influenza Risk Mapping and Risk Based Surveillance Train the Trainer course was held in the Dominican Republic. This was the second part of a training led by the CIRAD group. The first part was held in November 2015 and focused on basic GIS and mapping skill development. This goal of this second part was for students to complete an Avian Influenza Risk map for their particular country.

title.narrative: Japan - Asian Gypsy Moth Port Outreach

description.narrative: The project was directly involved in the on-going, established US-Canada-Japan AGM offshore summer ship inspection & certification program in Japan. The program safeguards North American forests from the introduction of AGM from Japan from the pathways of ships suprastructure and bulk or container cargo carrying life-forms of AGM into urban and rural parks and forests.

title.narrative: Caribbean - Greater Caribbean Region Lab training and development

description.narrative: As a result of expanding trade and tourism industries in the Caribbean, this area has long been recognized as a stepping stone for pests to enter the United States, especially via Florida. With 28 air and sea port, Florida serves as the first point of entry to the US mainland for many products and passengers for the Caribbean. In light of this there is need for the Region to have the capacity and ability to rapidly and accurately diagnosis plant and animal health problems to ensure the safe and sustainable trade of agricultural and animal products that are demanded by the U.S market and have access to relevant and scientific information systems to address trading partners requests.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Enhanced produce inspection techniques

description.narrative: Pests and insects interceptions in the United States have been a serious challenge for fruit and vegetables exporters in the Dominican Republic (DR). Despite efforts made by the DR Ministry of Agriculture and producers/exporters to address the issue of increased pest interceptions at the U.S. Ports of entry, pests such as thrips remain a serious problem. In August 2017, a mission from Miami Airport Authorities and APHIS-PPQ, delivered a conference on market requirements and entry procedures of the U.S. The APHIS team explained the importance of proper inspection and export certification system to detect pests prior shipping. The APHIS team also visited two packing houses and highlighted some weak points that may affect the quality of the inspections. The Export Quality and Safety Program (EQS) implemented by IESC (International Executive Service Corps) is providing support to improve the DR inspection system (infrastructure, training, tools, etc.) following the recommendations provided by APHIS. In this projects, APHIS conducted additional, follow-up hands-on and in-depth trainin

Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account

title.narrative: National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) Technical Assistance on AI Diagnostics

description.narrative: APHIS NVSL assisted the Dominican Republic National Veterinary Laboratory (DRNVL) in implementing transcription -polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) testing for avian influenza in 2013. Since then, the DRNVL has tested hundreds of samples under the DR Avian Influenza (AI) and Newcastle national surveillance program. On September 30th, 2017 abnormal mortality and egg drop production were reported in one poultry farm located in the largest poultry production region in the Dominican Republic. DRNVL confirmed AI through testing and sent samples were to NVSL in Ames, Iowa, for confirmatory testing, where H5N2 was confirmed. The DR veterinary authorities requested an urgent conference call with NVSL-Ames experts to address some concerns regarding problems and inconsistencies with the DRNVL AI diagnostics. NVSL- Ames immediately donated PCR reagents to DRNVL and provided technical assistance first through email and phone calls and then through a visit to address the problems on site.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Emergency Response and disaster reduction panel

description.narrative: The 2018 CaribVET Meeting included a special session on emergency response and disaster reduction. Topics addressed included: introduction to Good Emergency Management Practice (GEMP), Avian Influenze (AI) Risk communication, updates on the AI situations of Belize and Dominican Republic, and AI risk mapping. An APHIS subject matter expert attended and initiated discussions on planning relevant stakeholders in the Caribbean.

title.narrative: Surveillance and Preparedness for Viral Swine Foreign Hemorrhagic Fevers

description.narrative: The training will enhance detection capabilities for potential African swine fever (ASF) introductions to the Dominican Republic and other Caribbean countries to prevent the spread in country and the region and enhance surveillance for classical swine fever to better assess disease status and distribution. It will also develop diagnostic capabilities for ASF detection and overall diagnostic preparedness for swine foreign hemorrhagic fevers in the Dominican Republic and other Caribbean countries.

title.narrative: African Swine Fever Compensation and Indemnization

description.narrative: In July 2021, APHIS confirmed the presence of African swine fever (ASF) in the Dominican Republic, near the border with Haiti. Epidemic outbreaks of ASF can result in significant economic impacts, depending on the duration of the outbreak, extent of trade embargoes, and reaction of producers and consumers to the disease and response measures. APHIS is providing support for the control and eradication of ASF in the Dominican Republic, as requested by the Dominican Republic Ministry of Agriculture. This project (conducted in cooperation with IICA) provides funding for the provision of indemnity to producers for pigs that are depopulated or slaughtered to control the spread of the disease.

participating-org.narrative: Inter-American Institute for Co-operation on Agriculture

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Accelerating the Control and Eradication of African Swine Fever through a National Biosecurity Program for the Pig Value Chain in the Dominican Republic

description.narrative: This activity will support the development of a national biosecurity program for both backyard and commercial pig farmers in the Dominican Republic as well as other entities in the pig value chain. It will include baseline studies to determine areas at high-risk for exposure to African swine fever and development of standard operating procedures for farmers, markets, and slaughterhouses; draft biosecurity legislation for consideration; and information systems and outreach materials. The project will also support implementation of biosecurity activities in select high-risk areas.

title.narrative: Food for Progress

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.
